awd_titl_txt: TWC: Small: Hardware Security for Embedded Computing Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Embedded processing systems are widely used in many devices and systems that are essential for daily life. These embedded systems are increasingly connected to networks for control and data access, which also exposes them to remotely launched malicious attacks. It is of paramount importance to develop embedded processing systems that are hardened to withstand these remote attacks while continuing to operate effectively. Since embedded systems are often used in real-time environments with lightweight operating systems and limited processing and power resources, conventional software solutions for malware detection are not suitable in this domain. Instead, architectural solutions that are specialized to embedded processing systems are necessary. 

This project develops a comprehensive attack detection and mitigation system that is based on hardware monitors that are co-located with the embedded processor. The hardware monitor tracks the operation of the processor and compares each executed instruction with a model of the application that was created by analyzing the original binary. Changes in operation caused by an attack can be detected within one cycle, and recovery steps can be taken. The proposed system does not require any changes to the software running on the processor and does not cause any reduction in processing speed. This project aims to realize a transformational shift in embedded system security from software-based defenses to hardware-based defenses. The results from this research address current security shortcomings and provide solutions that make embedded processors more resilient.

por.por_cntn:
Computer system security is of great concern in a cyber-connected world. This project developed a series of technologies that make embedded processing more secure and resilient against attacks.

The primary outcome of this project is the successful implementation of an instruction-based hardware monitor for microprocessors that can detect a stack-smashing attack within a single instruction execution. Our work dramatically increases the practicality of processor monitoring by allowing for the simultaneous evaluation of multiple threads of computation orchestrated by an embedded operating system. Since the monitoring system is isolated from performance-critical portions of the microprocessor, overall application performance is unaffected by monitoring. Our system allows for the detection of attacks on both user applications and the embedded operating system. No change to a user's application binary or operating system binary is needed. As an example, we showed that our programmable monitor can protect an embedded microprocessor's ability to perform blockchain operations, enabling secure financial transactions for mobile devices. The monitor's programming information can be dynamically and securely updated as an application's functional needs change.

Microprocessor cores and monitors have been implemented in digital hardware to evaluate high-performance operation.  As a result, two additional intellectual outcomes have been achieved for this project. We have evaluated the effectiveness of monitoring Linux system calls in hardware and shown that operating system execution can be performed at hardware speeds. Our approach was shown to successfully defend against a known Linux exploit, proving the practicality of the work. Additionally, a hardware demonstration of a stack smashing attack used to disrupt an Internet-of-Things transaction was implemented. Not only was the attack prevented using our monitoring system, but the user was notified of the prevented attack, allowing for timely countermeasures.

The broader impacts of this project have focused on societal impacts and education. The research results from this work are of value to society since embedded systems with hardware monitors can protect against certain types of computer malware. Research topics from the project have been integrated into multiple undergraduate and graduate courses at the University of Massachusetts Amherst on computer architecture and networking. Three doctoral students have been supported by this research. Research results have been published at top conferences and journals. The doctoral students organized several study groups for other students to educate them about the use of microprocessor monitoring. Three REU students engaged in summer research projects related to hardware monitoring.
